content:
Ok, it should not be normally, but I have altered this puzzle slightly after a Forum discussion. Apparently, there were some hidden edge cases: failing on either test or validator number 5 (or both) depending on rounding (up, down or both). Changes made:
- In the statement, it is added that rounding should not happen at all;
- Test/validator 5 are changed to make them similar (they fail now both if there is rounding or rounding up)
- Test/validator 6 is added (they fail both if there is rounding or rounding down)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A more difficult easy puzzle compared to others, should provide a good challenge for those between easy and medium level difficulties.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great easy level puzzle! Just enough twists and turns to keep the puzzler a little frustrated which leads to a nice feeling of accomplishment when finished.

Great job Flash! So, what do you call a three humped camel?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good one, hope this gets approved this time

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Goal section
* Please change "they each have" to "each of them has".

* You may simplify "Written example" to "Example".

* Please change "come ti" to "come to".

* Please mention how rounding should be performed during the calculations.

Input section
* Please change "int" to "integer" (3 times).

* Suggest to change "should be worked" to "a counter should work".

* Please mention "in minutes" for Line 5.

Constraints section
* In Test 3 and Validator 3, [[worktime]] in input is outside the range indicated by the first constraint. Please fix either the cases or the constraint.

Stub generator
* Please use loopline instead of string for Lines 3 and 5.

Issue arising from the example
* I've tried to solve your example with your code. So the input is:
20
2
1 2
3
30 40 10
And the output is:
1 2
1 1
OK, that is the same as what is stated in the example.
How about swapping the two counters and the first two customers? Input becomes:
20
2
2 1
3
40 30 10
And the output becomes:
2 1
1 0
Now that's odd. Should changing the order affect the number of breaks taken?

Thanks.

Wow, thanks as usual! I believe I've implemented your comments.

As per your issue regarding the example: I have been puzzling a bit on how to introduce the break time. I settled for the following: any break started while there are still visitors in line, is counted as break - even if during that break the line is resolved by other counters. If however the break would start at a moment that there are no visitors in line anymore, that break is not counted (the work is simply finished).

For the swapped case:
First visitor is helped in 20 minutes at first counter, second visitor is helped in 30 minutes at second counter. After 20 minutes, at the first counter the break starts, finishing at 20+10 = 30 minutes. After 30 minutes, we have the following situation: first counter has had 1 visitor, one break, and second counter has just finished 1 visitor. Automatically, the third visitor will go for the first counter -- the second counter is just about to start it's break, but there is no need for the break any more, because the line of visitors is already resolved. So, no break for the second counter.
--> Output: 2 1 visitors, 1 0 breaks.
Thanks! While submitting it the second time I simplified title and statement a bit, so maybe that will bring others over the bridge as well - anyway thanks for your support.

Pregnant camel!

Thanks for the positive feedback.
Cool, thanks for the approval, and nice that it proves a bit of a challenge :-).

Haha!  The same thing that you'd call a camel without ANY humps...


... you'd call him "Humphrey"

(Pronounced:  Hump-free / Hump-three)

You must be a dad because that is definitely a “dad joke” and I am going to reuse that joke a bunch! (Hopefully “dad joke” makes sense in the UK!)

“Pregnant camel“ comes from a classic scene in the movie Zootopia. Go to YouTube and look up “Zootopia sloth scene“. The heroes of the movie are trying to look up a license plate. They need help from the helpdesk of course, but at the helpdesk is a sloth. Very funny movie scene!

Yeah, we use the same term here ; )

But, man, that movie sounds hilarious... a sloth in a callcentre?  Freakin' genius!    ; ))))))

Thanks Tim,

>Movie downloading<

Thank you for your reply.

My thought is that, at the end of 30 minutes, one counter has just finished a break, and another counter has just finished helping a visitor. If we ignore the order of the counter, it is natural that the counter which is coming back from break serves the remaining visitor, and the other counter can just go home without taking a break (as there are no more visitors anyway).

I understand your logic, but it just feels odd to me that different orders result in different conclusions. It's like splitting the decision-making process at Minute 30 into Minute 30.1: let counter 1 take a break, Minute 30.2: counter 2 help the remaining customer.

I have a suggestion to avoid such a situation: actions should be assigned based on the type of actions first, and the order (index) of counters next.

By "type of actions" I mean, at any particular minute, if there are multiple available counters:
(a) Some counters are not entitled to breaks yet - assign customers to them.
(b) Some counters are entitled to breaks, but they will take a break only if there are still customers to be helped.
(c) If there are no more customers, ALL remaining counters (whether they are entitled to breaks or they are NOT YET entitled to breaks) can leave without taking a break.

It's just a suggestion. And it's absolutely ok to keep the rules the way you want it :)

I would prefer to give you 5 upvotes instead of only one for your sharpness as well as constructive thinking along -- accidently with my example I had a logically weird case. For the nature of the story, it would indeed make sense that, because at minute 30 the last customer can be helped by the second counter, the first counter does not need its break any more. It took me however a bit of puzzling to include that in my code (it is in there now, but not yet in the best way, I think). I do like that it is in there now, because it is always nice if a story is logically correct and that this correctness leads to a twist for the coding solution.

So, I fully agree with you. I have not (yet) included the 'order of actions' as text in the statement, but I did add the specification that a counter will never start on a break at the same time helping of the last customer starts, and I have changed the example text. I've added the example itself as fifth test as well.

Haha, thank you for your comment :D It's lucky that you've included that example, otherwise I may not have drilled down in such detail :P

Take your time to update the text. In the meanwhile I would suggest you to move the newest cases as the first pair - the simplest ones should go first, especially when there is association explanation in the statement.

You may also want to think whether additional test cases would be needed to cover the case of "counters not yet entitled to breaks but there are no more customers waiting" (I mean, like there are three categories of counters as per my last comment), if no such cases are there yet.

Just let me know when you're done, and I'll take another look :wink:

I have updated the order of cases - but the 'weird' example case I did not put at the front, because it is the logically more challenging one. Now, the order of cases covers 'clearly no break in sight' (cases 1, 2), breaks at clear moments (case 3) and the 'just finished before the break' situation (case 4). The final case has simply a lot of breaks, and also one moment of 'just finished before the break'.

Also, I have changed the example described in the statement; it is now the 'swapped case' that came across in our discussion - that one needed less logical steps in the explanation (and therefore keeps the 'go home if there are no more customers' issue partly as a surprise for case 4).
